bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a forest stewardship plan is amended to remove the holder of a licence or an agreement as a party to the plan, subsection (1) continues to apply to that holder in respect of any area that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in a forest development unit included in the plan, and
subject to a cutting permit or road permit issued in respect of the plan before the plan was amended.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person carrying out

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a forest practice, or
a range practice

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: that directly or indirectly removes or renders ineffective a natural range barrier must carry out measures that are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: specified in an operational plan for the area, or
authorized by the minister

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: to mitigate the removal or the ineffectiveness of the natural range barrier.
Despite expiry of the operational plan referred to in subsection (1) (c), subsection (1) continues to apply to the holder of that plan in respect of any area that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in a forest development unit included in the plan, and
subject to a cutting permit or road permit issued in respect of the plan before the plan expired.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a forest stewardship plan is amended to remove the holder of a licence or an agreement as a party to the plan, subsection (1) continues to apply to that holder in respect of any area that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in a forest development unit included in the plan, and
subject to a cutting permit or road permit issued in respect of the plan before the plan was amended.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Exemption for fighting out of control fire
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person does not contravene this Act or the regulations by doing or omitting to do something that is reasonably necessary to control a fire, unless the person knows or reasonably ought to know, that an official has declared that the fire is under control.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not cause or permit livestock to be driven on or to graze on Crown range unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: authorized to do so under an agreement under the Range Act or under the regulations under this Act, and
the person acts in accordance with this Act, the regulations, the standards and any applicable range use plan or range stewardship plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not cut, remove, damage or destroy hay on Crown range unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: authorized to do so under an agreement under the Range Act or the regulations under this Act, and
the person acts in accordance with this Act, the regulations, the standards and any applicable range use plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless authorized in writing by the minister, a person must not

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: store hay on Crown range, or
carry out, construct, modify, remove, damage or destroy a range development on Crown range.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person, other than the holder of an agreement under the Range Act, must obtain the authorization of the minister before maintaining a range development on Crown land.
The minister may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require a person seeking authorization under this section to submit the matter for which the authorization is sought for review in accordance with prescribed requirements, and for comments by interested parties during the course of the review,
grant or refuse the authorization, depending on the outcome of a review required under paragraph (a), and

impose pre-conditions or conditions of an authorization that the minister considers necessary or desirable, to be met by the person, including, but not limited to, requiring that the person provide security.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may grant an authorization under this section only if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: it is consistent with any range use plans, range stewardship plans and objectives set by government for the area covered by the authorization, and
the minister is satisfied that the authorization will adequately provide for the range resources of the area to which it applies.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the minister requires security under subsection (3) (c), the minister may specify

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: when the security must be paid,
the amount of security that is required,
the form of the security, and
the circumstances under which the security may be realized.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who obtains an authorization under this section must comply with any conditions of the authorization.
If the minister determines under section 71 that a person has contravened subsection (1) or (6), the minister may order the person to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: remove or destroy or remove and destroy the stored hay or the range development,
restore the land under the stored hay or the range development, or both, or
repair or rehabilitate the range development.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If satisfied that a range development is not effective, or is no longer needed for its original purpose, the minister may order the person responsible for the range development to remove it and rehabilitate areas that were affected by it.
The minister may revoke or vary an authorization under this section.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Unauthorized Timber Harvesting, Trespass and Tree Spiking

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not cut, damage or destroy Crown timber unless authorized to do so

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: under this Act, the Forest Act or an agreement under the Forest Act,
by the minister, for silviculture, stand tending, forest health, abating a fire hazard related to wildfires or another purpose,
under the Wildfire Act,
under a grant of Crown land made under the Land Act,
under the Park Act, or
under the regulations, in the course of carrying out activities

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: under an authorization referred in section 51 or 57, or
that are incidental to or required to carry out activities authorized or approved under this Act, the Forest Act, the Range Act or another prescribed enactment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person is authorized to cut, damage or destroy Crown timber for the purpose of carrying out a forest practice that is funded under a vote as defined in section 1 of the Financial Administration Act.
A person must not remove Crown timber unless authorized to do so

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: under the Forest Act or an agreement under the Forest Act,
under a grant of Crown land made under the Land Act, or
under the Park Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person, at the direction of or on behalf of another person,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: cuts, damages or destroys Crown timber contrary to subsection (1), or
removes Crown timber contrary to subsection (3),

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: that other person also contravenes subsection (1) or (3).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Authorization for silviculture, stand tending, forest health or another purpose

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister, in respect of an authorization under section 52 (1) (b), may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require the person seeking the authorization to submit the matter for which the authorization is sought for review in accordance with prescribed requirements, and for comments by interested parties during the course of the review,
grant or refuse the authorization, depending on the outcome of a review required under paragraph (a) of this subsection, and

impose pre-conditions or conditions of an authorization that the minister considers necessary or desirable, to be met by the person, including, but not limited to, requiring that the person provide security.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the minister requires security under subsection (1) (c), the minister may specify

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: when the security must be paid,
the amount of security that is required,
the form of the security, and
the circumstances under which the security may be realized.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who obtains an authorization under section 52 (1) (b) must comply with any conditions of the authorization.
The minister may revoke or vary an authorization under section 52 (1) (b).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Private land adjacent to Crown land

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before an owner or occupier of private land that is adjacent to Crown land authorizes another person to cut or remove timber from the private land, the owner or occupier must inform that other person of the boundaries of the private land.
Before a person cuts or removes timber from private land adjacent to Crown land, the person must ascertain the boundaries of the private land.

A person must obtain the consent of the minister before constructing or occupying a building or other structure on Crown land in a Provincial forest unless the construction or occupation is authorized under another enactment.
If the minister determines under section 71 that a person has contravened subsectionÂ (1), the minister may order the person to do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: remove the building or other structure;
destroy the building or other structure;
restore the land under the building or other structure.

bcl:section.bcl:text: On private land that is subject to an agreement under the Forest Act or on Crown land, a person must not

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: drive or place any nail, spike or other potentially hazardous object into any timber that the person does not own or is not authorized to alter,
possess any nail, spike or other potentially hazardous object with the intention of driving or placing it into any timber that the person does not own or is not authorized to alter, or

solicit funds or materials from another person with the stated intention that the funds or material will be used to enable any person to drive or place any nail, spike or other potentially hazardous object into any timber that the person does not own or is not authorized to alter.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Interpretive forest sites, recreation sites and recreation trails

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may order

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the establishment of Crown land as an interpretive forest site, a recreation site or a recreation trail, except Crown land that is subject to another enactment and is being administered by another minister, branch or agency of government,
the variance of the boundaries of an interpretive forest site, a recreation site or a recreation trail, and
the disestablishment of an interpretive forest site, a recreation site or a recreation trail.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may establish an objective for an interpretive forest site, recreation site or recreation trail established under subsection (1).
An objective established under subsection (1) must be consistent with objectives set by government that pertain to the area.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Unauthorized trail or recreation facility construction

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless authorized in writing by the minister or under another enactment, a person must not

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: construct,
rehabilitate, or
maintain

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: a trail or other recreation facility on Crown land.

The minister may impose pre-conditions or conditions of an authorization that the minister considers necessary or desirable, to be met by the person, including, but not limited to, requiring that the person provide security.
If the minister requires security under subsection (2), the minister may specify

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: when the security must be paid,
the amount of security that is required,
the form of the security, and
the circumstances under which the security may be realized.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who obtains an authorization under subsection (1) must comply with any conditions of the authorization.
If the minister determines under section 71 that a person has contravened subsection (1), the minister may order the person to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: remove or destroy or remove and destroy the trail or facility, and
restore the land underlying the trail or facility.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may revoke or vary an authorization granted under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Protection of recreation and range resources on Crown land

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the minister determines that it is necessary to protect a recreation or range resource or to manage public recreation use on Crown land, he or she by order may restrict or prohibit

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a non-recreational use of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: any of the following established under the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act for recreation:

bcl:clause.bcl:text: a resource management zone;
a landscape unit;
a sensitive area, or

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: any of the following that is on Crown land:

bcl:clause.bcl:text: an interpretive forest site;
a recreation site or recreation trail,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: except any non-recreational use permitted under the Coal Act, the Mineral Tenure ActÂ or the Energy Resource Activities Act, or
a recreational use anywhere on Crown land, except a use that is specifically permitted under another enactment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may make different orders under subsection (1) for different uses and locations.
The minister must post a notice of an order under subsection (1) in the area to which the order applies.
Without lawful authority, a person must not remove, alter, destroy or deface a notice posted under subsection (3).

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Part, the Acts means one or more of this Act, the regulations or the standards or the Forest Act, the Range Act or a regulation made under the Forest Act or the Range Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applicability of certain provisions of Part 6 of this Act for the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Sections 59 to 70, 71 (1), (2), (5) and (6), 72 to 86, 88 to 96, 98 to 101 and 103 of this Act apply to and in respect of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act, and
the regulations or standards under that Act

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: in relation to the period that ended at midnight on January 30, 2004.
Subject to section 36 (1) (d) of the Interpretation Act, for contraventions of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act, or
the regulations or standards under that Act

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: that occurred before midnight on January 30, 2004,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the maximum administrative penalties, and
the maximum fines and periods of imprisonment

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: are as provided for under the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act at the time of the contravention.
For the purposes of this section,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the references in section 67 of this Act to sections 52, 50 (2) and 51 must be read as references to sections 96, 100 and 101, respectively, of the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act,
the reference in section 68 (1) of this Act to section 50 (1) must be read as a reference to section 98 of the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act,
the reference in section 71 (2) (a) (i) of this Act to an administrative penalty in an amount that does not exceed a prescribed amount must be read as a reference

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: to

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the penalty provided for under section 117 (1) of the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act, up to and including the amount provided for under that provision, or
that penalty plus the additional penalty provided for in section 119 (3) of that Act, up to and including the amount referred to in that provision, or

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: to

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the penalty provided for in section 119 (1) of the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act, up to and including the amount referred to in that provision, or
that penalty plus the additional penalty provided for in section 119 (3) of that Act, up to and including the amount referred to in that provision,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the references in section 90 of this Act to sections 26 (6), 51 (7), 54 (2), 57 (4), 66 (1) and 74 (1) must be read as references to sections 106 (1), 101 (2), 99 (2), 102 (3), 123 and 118, respectively, of the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act,
the reference in section 93 of this Act to section 46 (1) must be read as a reference to section 45 (1), (3) or (4), as applicable, of the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act,

the references in section 93 of this Act to sections 50 (1), 54 (1), 55 and 57 (1) must be read as references to sections 98, 99 (1), 103 and 102 (1), respectively, of the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act,
the references in section 94 of this Act to sections 52 and 53 must be read as references to sections 96 and 97, respectively, of the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act,
the reference in section 95 of this Act to section 50 must be read as a reference to section 100 of the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act, and
the reference in section 96 of this Act to section 57 must be read as a reference to section 102 of the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: [Repealed 2005-31-3.]
In subsection (2), dwelling means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a structure that is occupied as a private residence, and
if only part of a structure is occupied as a private residence, that part of the structure.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For any purpose related to the administration or enforcement of the Acts or an agreement under the Forest Act or the Range Act, or related to the verification of a statement made in an application for an agreement under the Forest Act or the Range Act, an official may enter, at any reasonable time, on land or premises, other than a dwelling, if the official has reasonable grounds to believe that the land or premises

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has located on it timber that is required to be scaled or marked with a timber mark under the Forest Act,
is the site of a forest or range practice that is regulated under the Acts or is carried on by a person who is required under the Acts to hold a licence or permit to carry out that practice,
is the site of trading in botanical forest products, or
is the site of an activity that under the Acts requires a licence, a permit, a plan or an approval.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At any reasonable time an official may enter on land that is in or within 1 km of a forest to inspect for fire hazards if the official has reasonable grounds to believe that an activity is being carried out or a condition exists on the land that might cause or produce a fire hazard.
An official who enters on land or premises under this section may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: inspect anything or any activity that is reasonably related to the purpose of the inspection, and
require production for the purposes of inspection or copying of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a licence, a permit or an operational plan that is required for the activity, and
a record required to be kept under the Acts.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A peace officer has the powers and duties of an official under subsections (2) and (4) with respect to the enforcement of the provisions of the Forest Act and regulations respecting marine log salvage.

bcl:section.bcl:text: For any purpose related to the administration and enforcement of the Acts, an official or a peace officer may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require a person operating a vehicle or vessel to stop the vehicle or vessel, and
carry out an inspection of a vehicle or vessel,

bcl:section.bcl:text: if the official or peace officer has reasonable grounds to believe that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the vehicle or vessel contains or is transporting timber, special forest products, seed, botanical forest products or hay, or
a person is contravening or has contravened one or more provisions of the Acts.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may order the holder of an agreement under the Forest Act or the Range Act to produce to the minister specified records that are related to an activity that requires a licence, a permit, a plan or an approval under the Acts or under the agreement.

At any reasonable time, an official may enter the business premises of a holder of an agreement under the Forest Act or the Range Act in which records are kept, for the purpose of inspecting or copying records that are required to be kept under the Acts.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An official who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: under this Division enters onto land or premises, conducts an inspection, stops a vehicle or vessel or requests records, or
under Division 2 of this Part seizes goods

bcl:section.bcl:text: must provide proof of identity, on the request of the person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is in possession or apparent possession of the land or premises,
has apparent custody or control of the records or property being inspected,
is in charge of the activity being inspected, or
is operating a vehicle or vessel stopped under section 60.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The operator of a vehicle or vessel must stop the vehicle or vessel when required to do so by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a peace officer, or
an official referred to in section 60

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is in uniform,
displays his or her official badge, or
is in or near a vehicle or vessel that is readily identifiable as a government vehicle or vessel.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is in possession or apparent possession of the land or premises,
has apparent custody or control of the records or property being inspected,
is in charge of the activity being inspected, or
is operating a vehicle or vessel stopped under section 60,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: must produce if and as required by the official

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: proof of identity,
a licence, a permit or an operational plan held by the person under the Acts, or
a record required under section 59 (4).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Warrant to search and seize evidence

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A justice of the peace may issue a warrant under section 21 or 22 of the Offence Act to an official to enter premises and search for and seize evidence of a contravention of the Acts.
The Offence Act applies to the search and seizure.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An official exercising powers or performing duties or functions under this Part may be accompanied by a peace officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an official has reasonable grounds to believe that a person is contravening a provision of the Acts, the official may order that the contravention stop, or stop to the extent specified by the order, until the person has a required licence, permit, plan, approval, variance, exemption or other authorization.
An order to stop work under subsection (1) must be in writing and include all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the nature of the contravention;
the extent to which the contravention or activity must cease;
the date by which the requirements of paragraph (b) must be met;
notice of the person's right under section 80 to a review or under section 82 to an appeal;
an address to which a request for a review may be delivered.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to the methods of giving notice under section 110, the official who issues a stop work order may give it to a corporation or partnership, by giving the order to an individual who is working at the site on behalf of the corporation or partnership.

An official who exercises the discretion under subsection (3) must also notify the corporation or partnership as specified in section 110, within 72 hours after giving the order to the individual mentioned in subsection (3).
An order under this section may be made to apply generally or to one or more persons named in the order.
The official who issued an order under subsection (1) or the minister

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must rescind the order if the official or the minister determines that there were insufficient grounds for issuing the order, and
may rescind the order in prescribed circumstances.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Seizure of timber, chattels, hay, etc.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An official may seize the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Crown timber that the official has reasonable grounds to believe was cut or removed in contravention of section 52;
timber, lumber, veneer, plywood, pulp, newsprint, special forest products, wood residue and chattels on which the government has a lien under section 130 (1) (d) of the Forest Act;
timber, including special forest products, that the official has reasonable grounds to believe

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: was removed from land in contravention of section 84 (1) or (3) of the Forest Act,
is being or has been manufactured, sold or transported contrary to section 94 or 94.1 of the Forest Act,
is being transported outside British Columbia in contravention of section 127 of the Forest Act,
a person is attempting to remove from British Columbia in contravention of section 127.1 of the Forest Act,
is being or has been transported in contravention of any regulation made under the Forest Act, or
is mixed with timber to which this subsection applies;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: seed that the official has reasonable grounds to believe has been collected contrary to the prescribed requirements;
hay that the official has reasonable grounds to believe has been cut, removed or damaged contrary to section 50 (2);
hay that the official has reasonable grounds to believe has been stored contrary to section 51;
a botanical forest product that the official has reasonable grounds to believe has been obtained contrary to the regulations;
a vehicle or vessel transporting any of the following to which paragraphs (a) to (h) apply:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: timber;
timber products;
seed;
hay;
botanical forest products.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If satisfied, after reconsidering the circumstances of a seizure under this section, that there is no longer any basis for retaining the things seized, the official who seized the things may release them and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: return them to the person from whom they were seized, or
deliver them at the direction of that person to another person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: deal with, at his or her discretion, Crown timber seized under subsection (1) (a), seed seized under subsection (1) (e), hay seized under subsection (1) (f), botanical forest products seized under subsection (1) (h), or

after giving the person from whom the timber, chattels, timber products or hay seized under subsection (1) (b), (c) or (g) an opportunity to be heard, sell at a public auction the timber, chattels, timber products or hay.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If timber, chattels or timber products are sold under subsection (3) (b), notice of the public auction must be published at least 10 days in advance, in or near the area where the sale is to take place, and must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: specify the time and place of the auction, and
identify by name the person from whom the timber, chattel or timber product was seized.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the money realized from the public auction exceeds the money that is payable to the government, including interest and the costs of seizure, storage and sale, the surplus must be paid to the person who possessed the property when it was seized if the property is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: timber, a chattel or a timber product seized under subsection (1) (b), or
timber seized under subsection (1) (c) (v).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (5), if within 30 days after the sale a person other than the person referred to in subsection (5) serves a notice of a claim to the surplus on a person designated by the minister, the surplus must be retained until the determination of the respective rights of persons claiming the surplus.
The proceeds from the sale of timber, a chattel or a timber product seized and sold under this section, other than

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: timber, chattels or timber products referred to in subsection (5) (a) or (b), and
an amount equal to the costs of seizure, storage and sale

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: must be paid into the consolidated revenue fund, and an amount equal to the costs of seizure, storage and sale may be used to pay those costs or reimburse the payment of those costs.

A vehicle or vessel seized under subsection (1) (i) must be released from seizure once the timber, chattel, timber product, seed, hay or botanical forest product is delivered to a location specified by the official.
If an official has reasonable grounds to believe that a person has contravened section 50 (1), the official, or person authorized by the official, may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: drive the livestock that are the subject of the contravention from Crown range;
round up, seize, tranquilize and hold the livestock;
destroy the livestock if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the safety of a person acting under this section is threatened by an animal that is being driven, rounded up, seized, tranquilized or held,
it is impracticable to round up the livestock, or
it would be humane treatment to do so.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If livestock are held under subsection (1),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an official may return the livestock to the owner

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: on payment of the reasonable costs of driving, rounding up, seizing, tranquilizing, holding, maintaining and returning the livestock or of disposing of a destroyed animal, or
if satisfied, after reconsidering the circumstances that led to the livestock being held, that there is no longer any basis for holding the livestock, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minister may sell the livestock.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister, an official or a person authorized by an official must take reasonable care of livestock while driving, rounding up, seizing, tranquilizing, holding, returning or selling them under this section.
If livestock is sold under subsection (2)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the government must pay the balance of proceeds realized from the sale, after deducting the costs incurred for the driving, rounding up, seizing, holding and selling the livestock to a person who

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: provides evidence satisfactory to the district manager that the person owned the livestock immediately before the sale, and
applies in writing to the district manager for the balance within 6 months after the sale,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the balance of proceeds from the sale, after deducting the costs incurred for driving, rounding up, seizing, holding and selling the livestock, if not paid under paragraph (a), must be paid into the consolidated revenue fund, and
an amount equal to the costs of seizure, storage and sale may by used to pay those costs or reimburse the payment of those costs.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Common provisions for seizure and forfeiture

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may release things seized under section 67 or 68 and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: return them to the person from whom they were seized, or
deliver them at the direction of that person to another person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On a sale under section 67 or 68 the purchaser acquires absolute ownership free of encumbrances.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Without the permission of the minister a person must not, remove, alter, destroy or deface a notice posted by the government for the purposes of notifying the public of a seizure under section 67 or 68.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister, after giving a person who is alleged to have contravened a provision of the Acts an opportunity to be heard, may determine whether the person has contravened the provision.
After giving a person an opportunity to be heard under subsection (1), or after one month has elapsed after the date on which the person was given the opportunity, the minister,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if he or she determines that the person has contravened the provision,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: may levy an administrative penalty against the person in an amount that does not exceed a prescribed amount, or

may refrain from levying an administrative penalty against the person if the minister considers that the contravention is trifling and that it is not in the public interest to levy the administrative penalty, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may determine that the person has not contravened the provision.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to section 72, if a person's contractor, employee or agent contravenes a provision of the Acts in the course of carrying out the contract, employment or agency, the person also contravenes the provision.
If a corporation contravenes a provision of the Acts, a director or an officer of the corporation who authorized, permitted or acquiesced in the contravention also contravenes the provision.
Before the minister levies an administrative penalty under subsection (2), he or she must consider the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: previous contraventions of a similar nature by the person;
the gravity and magnitude of the contravention;
whether the contravention was repeated or continuous;
whether the contravention was deliberate;
any economic benefit derived by the person from the contravention;
the person's cooperativeness and efforts to correct the contravention;
any other considerations that the Lieutenant Governor in Council may prescribe.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the minister levies an administrative penalty against a person under this section or under section 74 (3) (d) the minister must give a notice of determination to the person specifying:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the provision contravened;
the amount of the penalty;
the date by which the penalty must be paid;
the person's right to a review under section 80 or to an appeal under sectionÂ 82;
an address to which a request for a review may be delivered.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of this section, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may prescribe administrative penalties that vary according to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the area of land affected by the contravention,
the volume of timber affected by the contravention,
the number of trees affected by the contravention,
the number of livestock affected by the contravention,
the amount of forage destroyed by the contravention, or
the amount of hay affected by the contravention.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Defences in relation to administrative proceedings
bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of a determination of the minister under section 71 or 74, no person may be found to have contravened a provision of the Acts if the person establishes that the

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: person exercised due diligence to prevent the contravention,
person reasonably believed in the existence of facts that if true would establish that the person did not contravene the provision, or
person's actions relevant to the provision were the result of an officially induced error.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Penalty revenue to be paid into special account
bcl:section.bcl:text: All revenue derived from administrative penalties levied under this Division must be paid into the Environmental Remediation Sub-account of the Forest Stand Management Fund special account established by the Special Accounts Appropriation and Control Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the minister determines under section 71 that a person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is the holder of an agreement under the Forest Act or the Range Act, or
is in a prescribed category of persons

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: has contravened a provision of this Act or a regulation or standard, the minister may order the person to do work reasonably necessary to remedy the contravention.

If the minister makes an order under subsection (1) of this section or under section 51 (7), 54 (2) or 57 (4), the minister or official, as the case may be, must give written notice, accompanied by the order, to the holder or person, specifying

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the provision contravened,
the work to be done to remedy the contravention,
the date by which the work must be completed,
the person's right to a review under section 80 or to an appeal under section 82,
the right under subsection (3) (b) of the minister to carry out the work, and
the right under subsection (3) (d) of the minister to levy an administrative penalty for the contravention.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person, by the date specified in a notice given under subsection (2), does not comply with an order of the minister under subsection (1) of this section or under section 51 (7), 54 (2) or 57 (4), the minister may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by order restrict or prohibit the person from carrying out the work referred to in the order;
carry out the work;

by order require the person to pay to the government the amount of all direct and indirect costs the minister determines were reasonably incurred in carrying out the work referred to in paragraph (b);
by order levy an administrative penalty not exceeding an amount that is the sum of the costs referred to in paragraph (c);
for the purpose of recovering the costs referred to in paragraph (c) or the administrative penalty referred to in paragraph (d), realize any security provided by the person under the regulations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister must give written notice of the completion of work carried out under subsection (3) (b) and of any order under subsection (3) (a) or (c) to the person to whom the notice under subsection (2) was given,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: informing the person of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the restrictions or the prohibition under an order under subsection (3) (a), and
the amount payable by the person to the government under an order under subsection (3) (c) and the person's liability under section 130 of the Forest Act to pay that amount,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: providing the person with a copy of the order under subsection (3) (a), and
providing the person with a copy of the order under subsection (3) (c) and with an accounting of the expenditures relating to the work.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister must give written notice to the person, who is the subject of an order under subsection (3) (d), providing the person with a copy of the order and informing the person of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount of the administrative penalty and the person's liability under section 130 of the Forest Act to pay that amount,
the reasons for the administrative penalty, and
the person's right to a review under section 80 or to an appeal under section 82, including an address to which a request for a review or appeal may be delivered.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The person immediately must replace security realized under subsection (3) (e).
The minister must refund to the person any surplus of funds remaining from the realization of a security under subsection (3) (e), after payment of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount of the costs referred to in subsection (3) (c), and
any administrative penalty levied under subsection (3) (d).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the holder of an agreement or another person who receives an order under subsection (1)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: carries out work specified in the order, and
incurs expenses in excess of the expenses that the person would have incurred if the order had not been made,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: and the order is rescinded on review or appeal, then, to the extent provided in the regulations, the excess expenses of the work are to be paid by the government.

The period during which an administrative penalty may be levied under section 71 (2) or 74 (3) (d) or an order may be made under section 74 (1) is 3 years beginning on the date on which the facts that lead to the determination that the contravention occurred first came to the knowledge of an official.

A document purporting to have been issued by an official referred to in subsection (1), certifying the date the facts that lead to the determination that the contravention occurred first came to the knowledge of the official,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is admissible in an appeal referred to in section 82 of the determination, without proof of the signature or official character of the individual appearing to have signed the document, and
in the absence of evidence to the contrary, is proof of the matter certified.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Extension of due date for administrative penalties and other charges, on review or appeal
bcl:section.bcl:text: Despite section 130 (1) (a) of the Forest Act, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order or other determination under this Act imposes an administrative penalty or other charge against a person, and
the person, under section 80 or 82 of this Act may request a review of the order or other determination or may appeal the order or other determination,

bcl:section.bcl:text: the penalty or charge is due and payable on the date the stay under section 78 of this Act ceases to apply.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister, by order that meets the prescribed requirements, may require a person who is the holder of an agreement under the Forest Act or the Range Act or is in a prescribed category of persons to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: remedy,
mitigate, or
stop,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: in a manner and to the extent that is reasonable in the circumstances, an act or omission of the person that the minister reasonably believes will result in a contravention of the Acts and will or probably will cause

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a catastrophic impact on public health or safety,
any prescribed event or circumstance that will result in a free growing stand required under this Act not being established, or
any prescribed event or circumstance having an adverse impact on the environment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the minister believes on reasonable grounds that a person is transporting or is about to transport beetle-infested timber and that the transportation of the timber will or probably will cause or has caused an adverse impact on the environment, the minister, by order that meets the prescribed requirements, may require the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to stop or refrain from transporting the beetle-infested timber, and
to carry out specified measures to reduce the potential for the adverse impact on the environment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may prescribe the circumstances in which and the conditions on which a person who has taken measures under subsection (1) or (2) may recover all or part of an amount reasonably incurred for the direct costs of carrying out the measures.

If an operational plan for an area is approved and the minister subsequently concludes, on the basis of information that was not known to the person who granted the approval, that carrying out a forest practice or range practice under the plan will continue or result in a potential unjustifiable infringement of an aboriginal right or title in respect of the area, the minister

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must notify the holder of the plan of the previously unavailable information,
by order given to the holder of the plan, may vary or suspend to the extent the minister considers necessary one or more of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the operational plan;
a forest practice or range practice;
a cutting permit;
a road permit, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by order given to the holder of a BC timber sales agreement who is operating under the plan, may vary or suspend to the extent the minister considers necessary one or both of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a forest practice;
a BC timber sales agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the holder of an agreement under the Forest Act or the Range Act is exempt under this Act from the requirement to have an operational plan for an area and the minister subsequently concludes, on the basis of information that was not known to the person who granted the exemption, that carrying out a forest practice or range practice under the exemption will continue or result in a potential unjustifiable infringement of an aboriginal right or title in respect of the area, the minister

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must notify the following of the previously unavailable information:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the holder of the agreement;
the timber sales manager, if the agreement is a BC timber sales agreement, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by order given to the holder of the agreement, may vary or suspend to the extent the minister considers necessary one or more of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the exemption, including any conditions associated with the exemption;
a forest practice or range practice;
a cutting permit;
a road permit;
a BC timber sales agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the minister considers that an order under subsection (1) (b) or (2) (b) is no longer necessary, in whole or in part, the minister must promptly rescind the order except for those aspects, if any, that the minister considers are still necessary.

If an order under this section requires the holder of an agreement under the Forest Act or the Range Act to carry out a measure that results in the holder incurring expenses that are greater than if the order had not been made, then, to the extent provided in the regulations, the additional expenses of the measure are to be paid by the government.

A determination that may be reviewed under section 80 or appealed under section 82 is stayed until the person who is the subject of the determination has no further right to have the determination reviewed or appealed.

Despite subsection (1), the minister may order that a determination, other than a determination to levy an administrative penalty under section 71 or 74 (3) (d) is not stayed or is stayed subject to conditions, on being satisfied that a stay or a stay without those conditions, as the case may be, would be contrary to the public interest.
Despite subsection (1), a determination is not stayed if the determination is made under prescribed sections or for prescribed purposes.
Within 15 days after a determination is made under section 16, 26 (2), 27 (2), 32 (2), 37, 51 (7), 54 (2), 57 (4), 66, 71, 74 or 77 of this Act, the person who made the determination may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: correct a typographical, an arithmetical or another similar error in the determination, and
correct an obvious error or omission in the determination.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The correction does not take effect until the date on which the person who is the subject of the determination is notified of it under subsection (4).
The discretion conferred under subsection (1)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is to be exercised in the same manner as the determination affected by it, and
is exercisable with or without a hearing and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: on the initiative of the person who made the determination, or
at the request of the person who is the subject of the determination.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The person who corrected a determination under this section must notify the person who is the subject of the determination.

Subject to subsection (2), at the request of a person who is the subject of a determination under section 16, 20 (3), 26 (2), 27 (2), 32 (2), 37, 38 (5), 39, 51 (7), 54 (2), 57 (4), 66, 71, 74, 77, 77.1, 97 (3), 107, 108, 112 (1) (a) or 155 (2) of this Act, the person who made the determination, or another person employed in the ministry and designated in writing by the minister must review the determination, but only if satisfied that there is evidence that was not available at the time of the original determination.
On a review required under subsection (1) the person conducting the review may consider only

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: evidence that was not available at the time of the original determination, and
the record pertaining to the original determination.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: To obtain a review of a determination under subsection (1) the person must request the review not later than 3 weeks after the date the notice of determination was given to the person.
The minister may extend the time limit for requiring a review under this section before or after its expiry.
The person conducting the review has the same discretion to make a decision that the original decision maker had at the time of the determination under the review.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Board may require review of a determination

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the board first receives the consent of the person who is the subject of a determination under section 16, 37, 71 or 74 of this Act, the board may require a review of the determination by the person who made the determination, or another person employed in the ministry and designated in writing by the minister.
To obtain a review of a determination under subsection (1), the board must require the review not later than 3 weeks after the date the notice of determination was given to the person.
The minister may extend the time limit for requiring a review under this section before or after its expiry.
The person conducting the review has the same discretion to make a decision that the original decision maker had at the time of the determination under the review.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Appeal to the commission by a person who is the subject of a determination

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The person who is the subject of a determination referred to in section 80, other than a determination made under section 77.1, may appeal to the commission either of the following, but not both:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the determination;
a decision made after completion of a review of the determination.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The board, if it so requests, has standing to be a party to an appeal under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Appeal to the commission by the board

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The board may appeal to the commission either of the following, but not both:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a determination referred to in section 81;
a decision made after completion of a review of the determination.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The board may apply to the commission for an order under section 84 (2) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minister authorized under section 71 or 74 of this Act to make a determination has not done so, and
a prescribed period has elapsed after the facts relevant to the determination first came to the knowledge of the official or the minister.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application of Administrative Tribunals Act to appeals under this Act
bcl:section.bcl:text: In addition to the provisions of the Administrative Tribunals Act incorporated under Part 8.1 of this Act, section 33 of that Act applies to appeals under sections 82 andÂ 83 of this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On an appeal

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by a person under section 82 (1), or
by the board under section 83 (1),

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the commission may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: consider the findings of the person who made the determination or decision, and
either

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: confirm, vary or rescind the determination or decision, or
with or without directions, refer the matter back to the person who made the determination or decision, for reconsideration.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On an application under section 83 by the board the commission may order the official or minister referred to in section 83 (2) to make a determination as authorized under the applicable provision that is referred to in section 83 (2) (a).
The minister must publish an annual report on enforcement activities.
The minister must keep and make available to the public a performance record for holders of agreements under the Forest Act and the Range Act.

The time limit for laying an information respecting an offence under the Acts is 3 years after the date on which the facts that lead to the laying of the information first came to the knowledge of an official.

A document purporting to have been issued by an official referred to in subsection (1), certifying the date on which the facts that lead to the laying of the information referred to in that subsection first came to the knowledge of the official,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is admissible without proof of the signature or official character of the individual appearing to have signed the document, and
in the absence of evidence to the contrary, is proof of the matter certified in the document.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who contravenes section 46 (1), 52 (1) or (3) or 112 (3) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding $1Â 000Â 000, or to imprisonment for not more than 3 years, or to both.

A person who contravenes section 21 (1), 22 (2), 29 (1) or (3) or 55 (a) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding $500Â 000, or to imprisonment for not more than 2 years, or to both.
A person who
commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding $100Â 000, or to imprisonment for not more than one year, or to both.

A person who contravenes section 53 (1) or (2), 55 (b) or (c), 57 (1) or (3), 58 (4) or 70 commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding $5Â 000 or to imprisonment for not more than 6 months, or to both.
The maximum fine to which a person is liable on a second or subsequent conviction for the same offence under subsections (1) to (4) is double the amount set out in the applicable subsection.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may provide by regulation that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a contravention of a regulation or standard is an offence, and
a person convicted of an offence for a contravention of a regulation or standard is liable to a fine not exceeding a maximum amount, or to imprisonment not exceeding a maximum length, or to both.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the maximum fine or imprisonment provided by a regulation under subsection (6) (b) is less than that provided by a provision of this Act, the regulation prevails.
A proceeding, conviction or penalty for an offence under this Act does not relieve a person from any other liability.
The provisions of this Part are in addition to the provisions of any other enactment or rule of law under which

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a remedy or right of appeal or objection is provided, or
a procedure is provided for inquiry into or investigation of a matter,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: and nothing in this Act limits or affects that remedy, right, objection or procedure.
The government may not proceed under this Act with both an offence and an administrative penalty for the same contravention.
Subsection (1) does not derogate from the government's ability to make an order respecting compensation or remediation.

If the minister considers that a person is not complying, or has not complied, with an order made under section 26Â (6), 27Â (2), 38Â (5), 39Â (2), 51Â (7), 54Â (2), 57Â (4), 58Â (1), 61Â (1), 66Â (1), 74Â (1) orÂ 77 of this Act, the minister may apply to the Supreme Court for either or both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order directing the person to comply with the order or restraining the person from violating the order;
an order directing the directors and officers of the person to cause the person to comply with or to stop violating the order.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On application by the minister under this section, the Supreme Court may make an order it considers appropriate.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a person is convicted of an offence under a provision of this Act or of the regulations, then, in addition to any punishment the court may impose, the court may order the person to comply with the provision.
If a person is convicted of an offence under this Act, then, in addition to any other penalty, the court may order the person to pay compensation or make restitution.

If a contravention of section 46 (1), 50 (1) and (2), 54 (1), 55 or 57Â (1) continues for more than one day, the offender is liable to a separate penalty, without notice and without a separate count being laid, for each day that the contravention occurs.

It is not a defence to a prosecution under section 52 or 53 that the person charged with the offence had the right to cut or remove timber on private land adjacent to Crown land and did not know the boundaries of the private land.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Prosecution for unauthorized grazing or unauthorized cutting or storage of hay
bcl:section.bcl:text: It is not a defence to a prosecution under section 50 that the person charged with the offence had the right to graze livestock or cut, remove or store hay on private land adjacent to Crown land and did not know the boundaries of the private land.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Prosecution for unauthorized trail or recreational facility construction
bcl:section.bcl:text: It is not a defence to a prosecution under section 57 that the person charged with the offence had the right to construct, rehabilitate or maintain a recreation site or trail

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on private land adjacent to Crown land and did not know the boundaries of the private land, or
on Crown land on which the person was authorized under another enactment to carry out the activities and did not know the boundaries of that parcel of Crown land.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, person acting in an official capacity means an individual who is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: employed under the Public Service Act or is a member of the board, the commission or the council, if any, or is a person retained under section 138 (2), and
exercising a power or performing a duty or function under this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: without lawful excuse, intentionally interfere with a person acting in an official capacity,
without lawful excuse, intentionally not comply with a lawful requirement of a person acting in an official capacity, or
intentionally make a false statement to, or mislead or attempt to mislead, a person acting in an official capacity.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may suspend or cancel

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a forest stewardship plan, a woodlot licence plan, a range use plan or a range stewardship plan, or
a permit under this Act

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: if the minister, after giving a person who is alleged to have contravened subsection (2) an opportunity to be heard, considers that the person has contravened subsection (2) and that a plan or permit has been obtained as a result of that contravention.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a person is convicted of an offence under this Act, then in addition to any other punishment that may be imposed, the court may, by order, do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prohibit the person from doing anything that may result in the continuation or repetition of the offence or contravention;
direct the person to take any action the court considers appropriate to remedy or avoid any harm to the environment that results or may result from the act or omission that constituted the offence;
direct the person to publish, at the person's own cost, the facts relating to the conviction;

direct the person to compensate the minister for all or part of the cost of any remedial or preventative action taken by or caused to be taken on behalf of the ministry as a result of the act or omission that constituted the offence;
direct the person to pay court costs;
direct the person to pay the costs of the investigation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The court that convicts a person of an offence under this Act may increase a fine imposed on the person by an amount equal to the court's estimation of the amount of the monetary benefit acquired by or that accrued to the person as a result of the commission of the offence.
A fine increased under subsection (1)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: applies despite any provision that provides for a maximum fine, and
is in addition to any other fine under this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In a prosecution for an offence under this Act, it is sufficient proof of the offence to establish that it was committed by the defendant's contractor, employee or agent.
This section applies even if the contractor, employee or agent has not been identified or prosecuted for the offence.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Due diligence, mistake of fact and officially induced error are defences to a prosecution under this Act.
If a corporation commits an offence under this Act, a director or officer of the corporation who authorized, permitted or acquiesced in the offence also commits the offence.
Section 5 of the Offence Act does not apply to this Act, the regulations or the standards.
For the purposes of any Act or law respecting libel or slander,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: anything said, all information supplied and all records and things produced in the course of an investigation, an inquiry or proceedings before the board, commission or council, if any, under this Act are privileged to the same extent as if the investigation, inquiry or proceedings were proceedings in a court, and

a report made by the board and a fair and accurate account of the report in a newspaper, periodical publication or broadcast is privileged to the same extent as if the report of the board were the order of the court.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person is liable to the government

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for costs incurred by the government in controlling or disposing of insects, diseases, animals or abiotic factors, and
the value of Crown timber damaged or destroyed or of forage damaged or destroyed,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: directly or indirectly, as a result of the person's non-compliance with an order under section 26 or 27.
A person is liable to the government for the market value of any

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: timber cut, damaged or destroyed without authorization under this Act, or
forage or hay cut, damaged or destroyed without authorization under this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person is liable to the government for an economic gain that results, directly or indirectly, from the person's act or omission that would have been a contravention or an offence under this Act if it were not for the defence of due diligence, mistake of fact or officially induced error.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In sections 107 and 108, operational plan includes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a forest development plan,
a logging plan,
a range use plan, and
a site level plan

bcl:section.bcl:text: to which Part 11 of this Act applies.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Limitation on liability of persons to government

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who is the holder of an agreement under the Forest Act or the Range Act or who meets the prescribed requirements may submit to the district manager a written declaration specifying

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: obligations under this Act, or under an operational plan, permit or other authorization, that have been fulfilled, and
any of the following things to which the fulfillment of the obligations is relevant:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: cutblocks and roads;
operational plans;
permits.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The declaration under subsection (1) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be signed by the person referred to in that subsection or on that person's behalf by an individual or the individuals authorized in that regard, and
specify the date on which the declaration is made.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsections (4) to (6), on the date of the declaration submitted and signed in accordance with subsections (1) and (2), the person who submitted the declaration is deemed to have fulfilled the specified obligations that are referred to in subsection (1) (a).
If

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within the prescribed period after receiving a declaration submitted by a person under subsection (1), and
after giving the person an opportunity to be heard,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the minister determines by order that an obligation specified in the declaration has not been fulfilled, the minister must give written notice of the order to the person, including with the notice the reasons for the order.

The minister must not give written notice under subsection (4) of an order to the effect that an obligation in respect of establishing a free growing stand on an area has not been fulfilled unless the minister has determined that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a free growing stand has not been established, or
a free growing stand has been established and the following circumstances apply:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: at the time the declaration was made, the stand was under threat from

bcl:clause.bcl:text: competing plants, shrubs or other trees established on the area, or
factors adverse to forest health in the area;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: as a result of the threats referred to in subparagraph (i), the stand is unlikely to remain a free growing stand without further treatment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who submits a declaration under subsection (1) remains responsible for fulfilling an obligation that under subsection (1) (a) was specified as having been met if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minister has determined by order under subsection (4), of which notice has been given in accordance with that section, that the obligation has not been fulfilled, or
the person

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: made a material misrepresentation or misstatement of fact in the declaration in relation to the obligation, or
omitted information from the declaration that the person knew or ought to have known was material to determining whether the obligation had been fulfilled.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Government may fund extra expense or waive obligation

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister must grant the relief described in subsection (3) to a person who has an obligation under this Act or an operational plan, other than

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an obligation to establish a free growing stand, or
a prescribed obligation, and

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: who satisfies the minister that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: because of an event causing damage, the obligation on the area cannot be met without significant extra expense than would have been the case if the damage had not occurred, and
the person

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: did not cause or contribute to the cause of the damage,
exercised due diligence in relation to the cause of the damage, or
contributed to the cause of the damage but only as a result of an officially induced error.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister must grant

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the relief described in subsection (3), or
the funding described in subsection (4)

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: to a person having an obligation to establish a free growing stand if the person satisfies the minister that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: because of an event causing damage, the obligation to establish the free growing stand cannot be met without significant extra expense than would have been the case if the damage had not occurred, and
the person

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: did not cause or contribute to the cause of the damage,
exercised due diligence in relation to the cause of the damage, or
contributed to the cause of the damage but only as a result of an officially induced error.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The relief, that must be granted under subsection (1) or that may be granted under subsection (2) (a), from an obligation by the minister to a person is relief from

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person's obligation to the extent only that the obligation cannot be met without significant extra expense related to the damage referred to in subsection (1) or (2), or
the person's obligation in full if the minister considers that the remaining obligation, after taking paragraph (a) of this subsection into account, is inconsequential.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The funding for an obligation, that may be granted under subsection (2) (b) by the minister to a person, is funding to the extent only that is required for the purpose of restoring the stand of trees on the area affected by the event referred to in subsection (2)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to the stage the stand had reached at the time of the damage caused by the event, or
to the stage that is consistent with an agreement between the person and the minister.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A decision in any proceedings, that a person having an obligation referred to in subsection (1) or (2) did or did not do any of the things referred to in subsection (1) (d) or (2) (d), is binding on the minister.
The minister may not under this section grant relief or funding in respect of an event causing damage if the event occurred before December 17, 2002.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations for the purposes of this section resolving any doubt as to what constitutes an event or as to when an event occurred.
In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: information includes a record;
person means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the government, board, commission or council, if any,
an employee, agent and independent contractor of the government, board, commission or council, if any, or
a member of the board, commission or council, if any.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Each of the following persons must take an oath that he or she will not disclose information obtained under this Act except as permitted by this section and under the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a member of the board, commission or council, if any;
an employee of the board, commission or council, if any;
a person appointed to carry out an audit referred to in section 122;
a specialist or consultant retained by the board, commission or council, if any.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not disclose any information obtained in the exercise of a power or the performance of a duty or function under this Act except

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: as required for the performance of his or her duties under this Act, or
as permitted in this section or under the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may disclose to the government any information obtained in the exercise of a power or the performance of a duty or function under this Act.
A notice or another document that the government or board is required or permitted to give to a person under this Act may be given by giving it, or a copy of it, to the person as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the person is an individual,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by leaving it with the individual,
by leaving it at the individual's last or most usual place of residence with someone who is or appears to be at least 16 years of age, or
by mailing it by registered mail to the individual's last known postal address;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the person is a corporation,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by leaving it with

bcl:clause.bcl:text: a director, an officer or a manager of the corporation,
a receptionist at a place of business of the corporation, or
if the corporation is an extraprovincial company within the meaning of the Business Corporations Act, the corporation's attorney, if any, within the meaning of that Act,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by leaving it at the registered office of the corporation if the corporation is a company within the meaning of the Business Corporations Act or, if that office has been eliminated under section 40 of the Business Corporations Act, the address ordered by the court under section 40 (4) (b) of that Act, or
by mailing it by registered mail to

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the registered office of the corporation or, if that office has been eliminated under section 40 of the Business Corporations Act, the address ordered by the court under section 40 (4) (b) of that Act,
if the corporation is an extraprovincial company within the meaning of the Business Corporations Act, the corporation's attorney, if any, within the meaning of that Act, or
an address provided by the corporation for service;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the person is a municipal corporation, regional district or other local government body, by leaving it with or sending it by registered mail to the local government corporate officer, the deputy of that officer or some similar local government officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice or another document that is mailed to a person by registered mail under subsection (1) is conclusively deemed to be received by the person on the eighth day after it is mailed.

A person who submits information to the government for the purposes of seeking approval by the minister in relation to a matter under this Act must ensure that, at the time the information is submitted, the information is complete and accurate.
A person who is required under this Act to submit information to the government must ensure that, at the time the information is submitted, the information is complete and accurate.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An order of the minister under this Act must be in writing and given to each person to whom the order pertains.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except in prescribed circumstances a person with a discretion under this Act to make an order, grant an exemption, give a consent, grant an approval, or grant an authorization under this Act may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: impose conditions that the person considers necessary or desirable in respect of the order, exemption, consent, approval or authorization, and
remove or vary the conditions by own motion or on the application of a person who is the subject of the order, exemption, consent, approval or authorization.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A condition imposed under subsection (1) is conclusively deemed to be part of the order, exemption, consent, approval or authorization in respect of which it is imposed, whether contained in or attached to it or contained in a separate document.
If a person is the subject of an order, exemption or condition under this Act, the person must comply with the order, exemption or condition.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister, or a person the minister authorizes in writing, may extend a time required to do anything under this Act other than

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an appeal of a determination,
the time within which a proceeding must or may be commenced,
the time within which the minister must give the notice referred to in section 107 (4), or
anything under the regulations or standards if the regulations or standards specifically provide otherwise.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A document purporting to have been issued by a minister referred to in the definition of "official" in section 1, certifying that the minister has designated a person as an official under this Act, is admissible as evidence of the designation without proof of the signature or official character of the minister purporting to have signed the document.
A power under this Act of the minister or an official to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make an order,
impose a fine or penalty, or
commence a proceeding

bcl:section.bcl:text: may be exercised separately, concurrently or cumulatively, and does not affect the exercise of any other powers of the minister, official or both under this or another enactment.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Amendment or remedial action does not affect offences or penalties

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An amendment to an operational plan does not affect any fine, imprisonment, fee, charge or penalty to which a person may be liable under this Act, if the offence or contravention occurred before the amendment.
The government may enter into agreements to assist in ensuring that forest resources and range resources are properly managed and conserved.
Without limiting subsection (1), on behalf of the government,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the chief forester or a person authorized by the chief forester may enter into agreements in respect of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the growing and disposing of seed and tree gene resources, and
intellectual property associated with seed and tree gene resources that is owned by the government,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an official designated by the minister may enter into an agreement with a person to develop, maintain or remove a range development,

an official designated by the minister may enter into agreements for the control and disposal of insects, diseases, animals and abiotic factors on forest land and for sharing costs of control and disposal,
the minister or an official designated by the minister may enter into agreements under which the government provides

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: forest or range protection services,
forest or range health services, or
services related to operations under agreements under the Forest Act that are carried out before or after timber is harvested, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an official designated by the minister may enter into an agreement with a person to develop, expand, maintain, repair or close an interpretive forest site, a recreation site or a recreation trail.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (4), an amount equal to any money paid to the government under an agreement referred to in subsection (2) (c) for a purpose specified in that subsection

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is appropriated for that purpose,
is in addition to any other amount appropriated for that purpose, and
is to be paid out of the consolidated revenue fund without any other appropriation other than this subsection.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (3) does not apply if the official designated to enter into the agreement is a BC Timber Sales official.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not evict, discharge, suspend, expel, intimidate, coerce, impose any pecuniary or other penalty on, or otherwise discriminate against, a person because that person complains or is named in a complaint, gives evidence or otherwise assists in respect of a prosecution, a complaint or another proceeding under this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If this Act, a regulation or a standard requires a person to perform an obligation or otherwise comply with this Act, the regulations or the standards, the person must do so at the person's own expense unless another provision of this Act or the regulations specifically provides otherwise.

If a person is required under this Act to submit an operational plan for approval to a person acting on behalf of the government, any implementation of the plan is at the person's own expense unless another provision of this Act or the regulations specifically provides otherwise.

Subject to a regulation made under section 141 (3) (b), each of the ministers responsible, respectively, for this Act, Part 7.1 of the Land Act and the Wildlife Act, in writing, may delegate a power or duty of that minister under this Act, including a quasi-judicial power or duty, to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person employed in a ministry,
a class of persons employed in a ministry, or
an agent of the Crown.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), a minister authorized by a regulation of the Lieutenant Governor in Council under section 149.1 (1) (a), 150 (1) (a), 150.1 (1), 150.2 (1) (a) or (b), 150.3 (1) (a) or (b), 150.5 (e), 154 (2) (a) or 157 (2) (d) to exercise a power or perform a duty may delegate that power or duty only to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person employed in a ministry, or
a class of persons employed in a ministry.
