bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In respect of a power or duty delegated under this section, this Act and the regulations and standards apply to the delegate as if the delegate were the minister who made the delegation.
A minister referred to in subsection (1) or (2) may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide directions that are binding on the delegate respecting the exercise of the power or the performance of the duty, and
vary or revoke a delegation or direction.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except in prescribed circumstances and if not prohibited by a direction of the minister under section 120.1Â (4)Â (a), a delegate under section 120.1 (1) may subdelegate the power or duty to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person employed in a ministry,
a class of persons employed in a ministry, or
an agent of the Crown.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except in prescribed circumstances and if not prohibited by a direction of the minister under section 120.1Â (4)Â (a), a delegate under section 120.1 (2) may subdelegate the power or duty to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person employed in a ministry, or
a class of persons employed in a ministry.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A document purporting to have been issued by a minister referred to in section 120.1 (1) or (2), certifying that the minister has made a delegation under this Act, is admissible as evidence of the delegation without proof of the signature or official character of the minister purporting to have signed the document.
In this Part and the regulations related to this Part, party means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the government,
the holder of an agreement under the Forest Act,
the holder of an agreement under the Range Act,
a person responsible for establishing a free growing stand as a result of an agreement referred to in section 29.1 (1) or (3),
a person responsible for maintaining or deactivating a road, under a regulation under section 155 (1) (d), or
a person referred to in section 122 (2) who may be audited or investigated under that section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In accordance with the regulations, the board

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must carry out periodic independent audits, and
may carry out special investigations

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: to determine

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: compliance with the requirements of Parts 2 to 5 and the regulations and standards made in relation to those Parts by a party, and
the appropriateness of government enforcement under Part 6.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: while carrying out under subsection (1) (a) or (b) an audit or investigation of a party in respect of a matter referred to in subsection (1) (c), the board finds that the party complied with the requirements audited or investigated, and
the only reason for that finding is that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the party exercised due diligence to prevent non-compliance,
the party reasonably believed in the existence of facts that if true would establish that the party complied with the requirement, or
the party's actions relevant to the requirement were the result of an officially induced error,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the board may audit or investigate whether a person other than that party did not comply with the requirements, in the course of acting for or at the direction of the party.
In accordance with the regulations, the board must deal with complaints from the public respecting prescribed matters that relate to this Act.
Despite subsection (1), the board may refuse to investigate a complaint, or may stop investigating a complaint, if, in the opinion of the chair, any of the following applies:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the complainant knew or ought to have known of the determination to which his or her complaint relates, more than one year before the complaint was received by the board;

the law or existing administrative procedure provides a remedy adequate in the circumstances for the person aggrieved and, if the person aggrieved has not taken advantage of the remedy, there is no reasonable justification for the failure to do so;
the complaint is frivolous, vexatious, not made in good faith or concerns a trivial matter;
having regard to all the circumstances, further investigation is not necessary in order to consider the complaint;
in the circumstances, investigation would not benefit the complainant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The board must promptly notify, in writing, the complainant and the party of its decision and the reasons for it and may indicate any other recourse that may be available to the complainant if it decides

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to not investigate or further investigate a complaint, or
that the complaint has not been substantiated.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting sections 122 and 123, for the purposes of those sections the board may investigate a determination.
The board may conduct an audit, a special investigation or a complaint investigation despite a provision to the effect that a determination is final and regardless of any right of appeal.
The board may not investigate conduct occurring before the commencement of Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act.
If a question arises as to the board's jurisdiction to investigate a case or class of cases, the chair may apply to the Supreme Court for a declaratory order determining the question.
The board may require a party to provide information or records related to an audit, a special investigation or a complaint investigation.
The board may require the party to provide the information in the form and manner the board considers appropriate.
The party must comply with a requirement of the board under subsection (1) or (2).
Without restricting subsection (1), the board may do all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at any reasonable time enter and inspect business premises occupied by a party, speak in private with any person there and otherwise investigate matters within the board's jurisdiction;
require a person to provide information or produce a record or thing in his or her possession or control that relates to an investigation at a time and place the board specifies;
make copies of information provided or a record or thing produced under this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the board obtains a record or thing under subsection (4) and the person from whom it was obtained requests its return, the board must, within 48 hours after receiving the request, return it to the person, but the board may again require its production in accordance with this section.
At any time while conducting an audit, a special investigation or a complaint investigation under this Act, the board may make an order requiring a person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to attend an oral or electronic hearing to give evidence on oath or affirmation or in any other manner that is admissible and relevant to an issue in the audit, special investigation or complaint investigation, or

to produce for the board a document or other thing in the person's possession or control, as specified by the board, that is admissible and relevant to an issue in the audit, special investigation or complaint investigation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The board may apply to the court for an order

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: directing a person to comply with an order made by the board under subsection (6), or
directing any directors and officers of a person to cause the person to comply with an order made by the board under subsection (6).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Contempt proceeding for uncooperative witness or other person
bcl:section.bcl:text: The failure or refusal of a person summoned as a witness under section 125 (6) to do any of the following makes the person, on application to the court by the board, liable to be committed for contempt as if in breach of an order or judgment of the court:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: attend a hearing;
take an oath or affirmation;
answer questions;
produce the records or things in their custody or possession.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Immunity protection for board and members

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, decision maker includes a board member, registrar or other officer who conducts an audit, a special investigation or a complaint investigation under this Act or a person who conducts a dispute resolution process for the purposes of this Act.
Subject to subsection (3), no legal proceeding for damages lies or may be commenced or maintained against a decision maker, the board or the government because of anything done or omitted

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the performance or intended performance of any duty under this Act, or
in the exercise or intended exercise of any power under this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (2) does not apply to a person referred to in that subsection in relation to anything done or omitted by that person in bad faith.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The board must not require information or a record to be produced if the Attorney General certifies that the giving of the information or record may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: interfere with or impede investigation or detection of offences,
involve the disclosure of the deliberations of the Executive Council, or

involve the disclosure of proceedings of the Executive Council or of any committee of the Executive Council, relating to matters of a secret or confidential nature, and would be harmful to the public interest.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Board must notify and consult party

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the board conducts an audit or investigation, the board must notify the party affected and any other person the board considers appropriate.
The board must consult with a party if the board receives a request for consultation from the party before the board has made its report under section 131.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If it appears to the board that there may be sufficient grounds for making a report or recommendation under this Act that may adversely affect a party or person, the board must inform the party or person of the grounds and must give the party or person the opportunity to make representations, either orally or in writing at the discretion of the board, before it decides the matter.

Evidence given by a person in proceedings before the board and evidence of the existence of the proceedings are inadmissible against the person in a court or in any other proceeding of a judicial nature except for the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the trial of a person for perjury;
the trial of a person for an offence under section 97;
an application for judicial review or an appeal from a decision with respect to that application.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Person may be reimbursed for expenses
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a person incurs expenses in complying with a request of the board for production of documents or other information, the board may reimburse that person for reasonable expenses.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (1.1), after completing an audit or investigation, the board must report its conclusions, with reasons, to any complainant, to the party and, if the government is not the party affected by the audit or investigation, to the ministers.
If an audit or investigation referred to in subsection (1) includes more than one party, the board may report its overall conclusions without reporting on compliance by each party.
If the board makes a report under subsection (1), it may make recommendations it considers appropriate.
Without limiting subsection (2), the board may make any of the following recommendations:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a matter be referred to the appropriate party for further consideration;
an act be remedied;
an omission or delay be rectified;
a decision or recommendation be cancelled or varied;
reasons be given;
a practice, procedure or course of conduct be altered;
an enactment or other rule of law be reconsidered;
any other steps be taken.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsection (1), the chair may, if the regulations provide and in the manner they provide, make an application under section 83 for an appeal of a determination or failure to make a determination.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Party to notify board of steps taken

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the board makes a recommendation under section 131 the board may request that the party notify it within a specified time

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: of the steps that have been taken or are proposed to be taken to give effect to its recommendation, or
if no steps have been taken or are proposed to be taken, of the reasons for not following the recommendation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, after considering a response made by a party, the board believes it advisable to modify or further modify its recommendation, the board must notify the party and the complainant of its recommendation as modified and may request that the party notify it

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: of the steps that have been taken or are proposed to be taken to give effect to the modified recommendation, or
if no steps have been taken or are proposed to be taken, of the reasons for not following the modified recommendation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The party must respond promptly to the board's request under subsection (1) or (2).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Report of board if no suitable action taken

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, within a reasonable time after a request by the board under section 132, no action is taken that the board believes adequate or appropriate, the chair may, after considering any reasons given by the party,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: submit a report on the matter to the ministers, and
after submitting a report under paragraph (a), submit a report to the Lieutenant Governor in Council respecting the matter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The chair

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must attach to the report a copy of the board's recommendation and any response made to the board under section 132,
must delete from his or her recommendation and from the response any material that would unreasonably invade any person's privacy, and
may in his or her discretion delete material revealing the identity of a member, an officer or an employee of a party.

bcl:section.bcl:text: After a complaint investigation, if the board makes a recommendation under section 131 or 132 (2) and no action that the board believes adequate or appropriate is taken within a reasonable time, the board must inform the complainant of its recommendation and make such additional comments as it considers appropriate.

If the chair considers a special report to be in the public interest, he or she may make a special report to the minister or comment publicly respecting a matter relating generally to the performance of the board's duties under this Act or to a particular case investigated by the board.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Forest Practices Board is continued.
The board consists of the following members appointed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council after a merit-based process:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a member designated as the chair;
one or more members designated as vice chairs after consultation with the chair;
other members appointed after consultation with the chair.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Sections 1 to 10, 44, 46.2 and 55 of the Administrative Tribunals Act apply to the board.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may determine the remuneration, reimbursement of expenses and other conditions of employment of persons appointed under the regulations to carry out audits.
Board members must faithfully, honestly and impartially perform their duties.
The board may organize itself into panels, each comprised of one or more members.
The members of the board may sit as a board or as a panel of the board, and 2 or more panels may sit at the same time.
A panel of the board has the jurisdiction of the board and may exercise the powers and perform the duties and functions of the board.
A report, a recommendation or an action of a panel of the board is a report, recommendation or action of the board.
Employees necessary to carry out the powers and duties of the board may be appointed under the Public Service Act.

In accordance with the regulations, the board may engage or retain specialists, consultants and auditors that the board considers necessary to carry out the powers and duties of the office and may determine their remuneration.
The Public Service Act does not apply to the retention, engagement or remuneration of specialists, consultants and auditors retained under subsection (2).

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person is not entitled to an oral hearing before the board.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The chair may delegate in writing to a person or class of persons any of the board's powers or duties under this Act, except the power

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: of delegation under this section, or
to make a report under this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A delegation under this section is revocable and does not prevent the board exercising a delegated power.
A delegation may be made subject to terms the chair considers appropriate.
If the chair makes a delegation and then ceases to hold office, the delegation continues in effect as long as the delegate continues in office or until revoked by a succeeding chair.
A person purporting to exercise a power of the board by virtue of a delegation under this section must, when requested to do so, produce evidence of his or her authority to exercise the power.
The Forest Appeals Commission is continued.
The commission is to hear appeals under

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 82 or 83, or
the Forest Act, the Private Managed Forest Land Act, the Range Act or the Wildfire Act and, in relation to appeals under those Acts, the commission has the powers given to it by those Acts.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The commission consists of the following members appointed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council after a merit-based process:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a member designated as the chair;
one or more members designated as vice chairs after consultation with the chair;
other members appointed after consultation with the chair.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The following provisions of the Administrative Tribunals Act apply to the commission:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Part 1 [Interpretation and Application];
Part 2 [Appointments];
Part 3 [Clustering];
Part 4 [Practice and Procedure], except the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: section 22 [notice of appeal (inclusive of prescribed fee)];
section 25 [appeal does not operate as stay];
section 33 [interveners];
section 34 (1) and (2) [party power to compel witnesses and require disclosure];

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Part 6 [Costs and Sanctions], except sections 47.1 [security for costs] andÂ 47.2 [government and agents of government];
Part 7 [Decisions];
Part 8 [Immunities];
section 59.1 [surveys];
section 59.2 [reporting];
Part 10 [Miscellaneous], except section 62 [application of Act to BC Review Board].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In accordance with the regulations, the commission must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: hear appeals under this Act, the Forest Act, the Private Managed Forest Land Act, the Range Act or the Wildfire Act,

provide the minister with an annual evaluation of the manner in which reviews and appeals under this Act, the Forest Act, the Private Managed Forest Land Act, the Range Act and the Wildfire Act are functioning and identify problems that may have arisen under the provisions of those Acts,

make recommendations to the minister annually, and at other times it considers appropriate, concerning the need for amendments to this Act, the Forest Act, the Private Managed Forest Land Act, the Range Act and the Wildfire Act and related regulations respecting reviews and appeals, and
perform other functions required by the regulations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The chair must give to the minister an annual report concerning the commission's activities.

The minister must promptly lay the report before the Legislative Assembly if it is in session or, if it is not in session when the report is submitted, file the report with the Clerk of the Legislative Assembly.
If the board may appeal a decision, order or determination, the board must do so no later than 60 days after the latest of the following to occur:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the original decision, order or determination;
any correction of the original decision, order or determination;
any review of the original decision, order or determination.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The board may apply for an order under section 84 (2) no later than 60 days after the period prescribed for section 83 (2) (b) has elapsed.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Persons and bodies entitled to notice and to be parties to appeal

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, minister means the minister responsible for the administration of the section of the Act under which the decision, order or determination giving rise to an appeal was made.
On receipt of a notice of appeal, the commission must give a copy of the notice of appeal to the minister.
On receipt of a notice of appeal in which the board has standing, the commission must give a copy of the notice,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if a person other than the board delivered the notice, to the board, or
if the board delivered the notice,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: to the person who is the subject of the determination, or
for an appeal of a failure to make a determination, to the person who would be subject to the determination, if made.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are parties to an appeal:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the government;
the board, if it has standing and so requests;
the person who is the subject of the determination or would be the subject of the determination, if made.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At any stage of an appeal, the commission or a member of it may direct that a person who may be affected by the appeal be added as a party to the appeal.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The commission may conduct an appeal by way of a new hearing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party to an appeal, or the minister, may appeal the decision of the commission to the Supreme Court on a question of law or jurisdiction.
An appeal under subsection (1) must be filed no later than 3 weeks after the date the person filing the appeal receives the decision of the commission.
On an appeal under subsection (1), a judge of the Supreme Court, on terms the judge considers appropriate, may order that all or part of the decision or order of the commission be stayed.
An appeal from a decision of the Supreme Court lies to the Court of Appeal with leave of a justice of the Court of Appeal.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations referred to in section 41 of the Interpretation Act.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting matters that are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: referred to in a provision of this Act as having to be in accordance with the regulations, or
indicated by a provision of this Act as being a matter for a regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsections (1) and (2), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: defining a word or expression used but not defined in this Act;
for the purposes of section 120.1 (1), specifying which powers and duties of a minister under this Act must not be delegated.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In making a regulation under this Act, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: delegate a matter to a person;
confer a discretion on a person;
make different regulations for different persons, places, things or transactions;
adopt the provisions of a publication or adopt them as they are amended from time to time.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may prescribe forms for this Act.

The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting the provision of information, to the minister or to an employee in the ministry of the minister responsible for the administration of this Act, including but not limited to regulations concerning matters related to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: agreements under the Forest Act, and
agreements under the Range Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsections (1) and (2), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting the form and manner in which, and time when, information must be provided.

The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting fees or charges for the provision under this Act to any person by the government, or by the board, commission or council, if any, under this Act, of a service or any property or use of property.

For the purpose of this section, the preparation of a range use plan or an amendment to a range use plan by the minister is a service provided by the government to the person required to follow the plan.
Subsection (1) applies whether or not there is an obligation on the government to provide the service, property or use of property.

The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting deposits and security of any kind, including but not limited to money, to be provided by the holder of an agreement under the Forest Act or the Range Act to ensure the performance of an obligation under this Act, the Forest Act, the Range Act or an agreement entered into under any of those Acts.
Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the type of security that is acceptable or unacceptable;
the form and content of the security;
the circumstances under which the security may be realized.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting the recovery of money that is required to be paid to the government under this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting the exemption of a person, place, thing or transaction from a provision of this Act, the regulations or the standards.
In making a regulation under subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make the exemption subject to conditions.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations restricting the minister's authority to exempt a person from a provision under this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Criteria for exercise of discretionary powers

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting the criteria that a person must use and the matters that a person must consider in exercising a discretionary power conferred on the person under this Act.
Criteria or matters prescribed under subsection (1) are additional to any criteria or matters that a person is required to use or consider in exercising a discretionary power under this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Interpretive forest sites, recreation sites and recreation trails
bcl:section.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting interpretive forest sites, recreation sites and recreation trails, including but not limited to regulations that restrict, prohibit or attach conditions to the use of the interpretive forest sites, recreation sites and recreation trails.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations prescribing objectives in relation to one or more of the following subjects:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: soils;
visual quality;
timber;
forage and associated plant communities;
water;
fish;
wildlife;
biodiversity;
recreation resources;
resource features;
cultural heritage resources.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In case of an inconsistency between

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an objective set by government prescribed under this section, and
an objective referred to in paragraph (b) or (c) of the definition of "objectives set by government" in section 1 (1),

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the objective referred to in paragraph (b) or (c) of that definition prevails to the extent of the inconsistency.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Ungulate winter range, wildlife habitat areas and general wildlife measures

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: authorizing the minister responsible for the Wildlife Act to establish one or more of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an area as an ungulate winter range and objectives for the ungulate winter range;
an area as a wildlife habitat area and objectives for the wildlife habitat area;
a general wildlife measure;
a general measure in relation to ecological communities;
categories of wildlife for the purposes of subparagraphs (i) to (iii),
categories of ecological communities for the purposes of subparagraph (iii.1), and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prescribing the circumstances in which the discretion conferred in the authorization may be exercised.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister responsible for the Wildlife Act may not establish an objective referred to in subsection (1) (a) (i) or (ii) for an area unless the objective is consistent with the objectives set by government that pertain to the area.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: authorizing

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the minister responsible for the Land Act to designate an area of land in a watershed as a community watershed, or
the minister responsible for the Water Sustainability Act to establish water quality objectives in relation to a community watershed, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prescribing the circumstances in which the discretion conferred in the authorization may be exercised.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting community watersheds, including but not limited to prescribing requirements in relation to community watersheds.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Watersheds with significant downstream fisheries values and significant watershed sensitivity

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations authorizing the minister responsible for the Wildlife Act to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: identify an area of land in a watershed that has

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: significant downstream fisheries values, and
significant watershed sensitivity, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: specify objectives in relation to the areas of land identified under this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister responsible for the Wildlife Act may not specify an objective referred to in subsection (1) (b) for an area unless the objective is consistent with the objectives set by government that pertain to the area.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: authorizing the minister to designate an area of land as a lakeshore management zone,
authorizing the minister to establish objectives in relation to lakeshore management zones,
prescribing the circumstances in which the discretion conferred in the authorization may be exercised, and
respecting lakeshore management zones.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may not specify an objective referred to in subsection (1) (b) for an area unless the objective is consistent with the objectives set by government that pertain to the area.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Scenic areas and visual quality objectives

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: authorizing the minister responsible for the Land Act to designate an area of land as a scenic area,
authorizing the minister to establish visual quality objectives in relation to a scenic area,
prescribing the circumstances in which the discretion conferred in the authorization may be exercised, and
respecting scenic areas.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may not specify an objective referred to in subsection (1) (b) for an area unless the objective is consistent with the objectives set by government that pertain to the area.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting objectives set by government and other objectives that are established under this Act, including but not limited to regulations

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting procedures and criteria that are to be followed in establishing objectives

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: referred to in paragraph (b) of the definition of "objectives set by government" in section 1 (1), or
other objectives that are established under this Act, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: resolving inconsistencies among those objectives by varying or limiting the application of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: objectives set by government, or
other objectives that are established under this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establishing criteria for classifying streams, wetlands and lakes,
respecting the classification of streams, wetlands and lakes,
establishing riparian reserve zones, riparian management zones and riparian management areas for different classes of streams, wetlands and lakes,
respecting

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: streams, wetlands and lakes, and
riparian reserve zones, riparian management zones and riparian management areas, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: authorizing the minister responsible for the administration of the Wildlife Act, in prescribed circumstances, to designate streams as temperature sensitive streams.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting operational plans, including but not limited to regulations prescribing

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: their form and content,
the form and content of maps included in the plans,
the manner of, and time for, submitting the plans for approval,
respecting the extension of the term for an operational plan,
amendments to plans including specifying what amendments are not minor amendments,
respecting balancing objectives or other plan contents when approving a plan, and
how a forest stewardship plan must take into account other currently existing or future forest stewardship plans.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting surveys, records and reports required or permitted under this Act.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting the transfer of obligations to establish a free growing stand, including but not limited to prescribing

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: stocking requirements that must be met, and
security that must be provided as part of the transfer of the obligation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Practices and planning â community forest agreements, woodlot licences

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: woodlot licences, woodlot licence areas and holders of woodlot licences, and
community forest agreements, community forest agreement areas and holders of community forest agreements.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establishing requirements and restrictions regarding the planning and forest practices, including the establishment of a free growing stand on a community forest agreement area or a woodlot licence area;
establishing conditions that must be complied with by the holder of a community forest agreement or a woodlot licence before, during and after forest practices;

requiring site plans to be prepared by the holder of a community forest agreement or a woodlot licence and approved by the minister before forest practices are carried out on the community forest agreement area or a woodlot licence area;
requiring that authority to carry out a forest practice on a community forest agreement area or a woodlot licence area be obtained before the forest practice begins;
requiring persons to carry out actions for maintaining or improving forest health;
establishing requirements for wildlife tree retention for areas within woodlot licence areas that apply despite any objective set by government with respect to wildlife tree retention;
establishing or varying objectives for ungulate winter range to reduce the impact to the allowable annual cut of a woodlot licence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting first nations woodland licences, first nations woodland licence areas and holders of first nations woodland licences, including regulations

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: without limiting section 146, providing that specified provisions of regulations made under subsection (1) or (2) do not apply to or in respect of first nations woodland licences, first nations woodland licence areas or holders of first nations woodland licences,

prescribing provisions, in addition to the provisions of regulations made under subsection (1) or (2), that apply to or in respect of first nations woodland licences, first nations woodland licence areas or holders of first nations woodland licences, and

varying provisions of regulations made under subsection (1) or (2) as the provisions apply to or in respect of first nations woodland licences, first nations woodland licence areas or holders of first nations woodland licences.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting forest resources and range resources.
Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: resource features, including but not limited to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: authorizing the minister to identify resource features other than a resource feature that is a wildlife habitat feature, and
authorizing the minister responsible for the administration of the Wildlife Act to identify a resource feature that is a wildlife habitat feature, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: forest health, including but not limited to forest health emergency management areas designated under section 27 (1).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the use of forest service roads, forest resource roads and rights of way;
the regulation or prohibition of the use and operation of vehicles or classes of vehicles on forest service roads, forest resource roads or rights of way;
the regulation or prohibition of road construction, maintenance or deactivation;

the transfer of an obligation to maintain or deactivate a forest service road or road that is authorized under an agreement under the Forest Act, including authorizing the minister to make orders that transfer obligations to maintain or deactivate a road;

requirements for the holder of an agreement under the Forest Act or a cutting permit to deactivate a road authorized or constructed under the agreement or permit, including but not limited to regulations requiring

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: roads to be deactivated by a prescribed date, or
plans or reports to be submitted;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: requirements for a person who uses a forest service road to provide notice to the minister or a prescribed person in relation to the person's use of the forest service road;
authorizing a person to fell trees, on Crown land in or adjacent to the right of way of a forest service road or forest resource road, that are a danger to persons or property;
the regulation of significant road work carried out in relation to forest service roads.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may exempt a person from all or part of a regulation made under subsection (1) (a) or (b), subject to conditions or alternative requirements the minister may specify.

For certainty, a regulation under subsection (1) (e) may be made applicable to a road that was authorized or constructed under an agreement or cutting permit before the date on which the regulation comes into force.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting timber harvesting practices including but not limited to restricting or prohibiting a timber harvesting practice.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting silvicultural systems and silviculture treatments.
Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: clearcutting, including but not limited to restricting or prohibiting clearcutting,
silviculture treatments, including but not limited to restricting or prohibiting various types of silviculture treatments,
rehabilitation of areas,
requirements for establishing a free growing stand on an area under an agreement under the Forest Act in which timber has been

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: harvested under an agreement under the Forest Act,
harvested from an area where the holder of the agreement is exempt from the requirement to prepare a forest stewardship plan or a woodlot licence plan,
damaged or destroyed by natural causes, or
harvested other than in accordance with this Act, the regulations and the standards, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: exempting persons from the requirements to establish a free growing stand under section 29 or on areas referred to in paragraph (d).

bcl:section.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting seed and tree gene resources including but not limited to regulations respecting the collection, processing, storage, registration, transportation, purchase, sale, selection, conservation and use of seed and tree gene resources.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting terrain stability and soil disturbance.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting cutblocks, including but not limited to regulations prescribing

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the size, including the maximum allowable size of a cutblock,
the shape of a cutblock, and
the spatial distribution of cutblocks, including green-up.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Use of Crown range and range developments

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting range practices, the use of Crown range and range developments.
Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the use of Crown range for grazing of livestock, hay cutting and other purposes;
promoting health of Crown range;
the identification of livestock pastured on Crown range;
range developments and the payment of costs for range developments.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations requiring persons to give written notice to an official concerning when, whether or not and to what extent the person has completed or will complete an obligation of the person under an operational plan or this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting administrative remedies under this Act, the Forest Act or the Range Act.
Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting charges and penalties in cases in which a person does not comply with one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: this Act, the regulations or the standards or the Forest Act, the Range Act or a regulation made under the Forest Act or the Range Act;
an operational plan;
a permit under this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting the levying of an administrative penalty or of administrative penalties in equal or unequal proportions against 2 or more persons involved in the contravention that gives rise to the penalty or penalties, including regulations prescribing

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: circumstances in which the penalties may be levied, and
formulas that may be applied in levying the penalties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting compliance with this Act and remediation related to a forest practice or range practice.
Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the power of the minister to require the holder of an agreement under the Forest Act or the Range Act to take action to achieve a requirement of this Act or the regulations or to prevent damage to the environment if the damage is associated with a forest practice, range practice or range authorization,
stop work orders, and
remediation orders.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting the review, correction or clarification of a determination under this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting appeals and the commission.
Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prescribing the period that must elapse after the facts relevant to a determination first come to the knowledge of an official or a minister before the board may apply to the commission for an order under sectionÂ 83;
prescribing the period in which the commission must deliver a decision after holding a hearing;
prescribing the form and content of annual reports made by the commission.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting the Forest Practices Board.
Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: audits referred to in section 122,
complaints to the board, including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the manner of making a complaint,
specifying which complaints may be heard,
the manner of dealing with complaints, and
the nature and extent of investigations which may be taken in relation to a complaint;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: procedures for notifying the board of determinations;
reports made by the board;
the qualifications of board members;
fees with respect to complaint investigations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting botanical forest products.
Without restricting subsection (1), Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: obtaining botanical forest products from Crown land;
identifying a plant or fungus that occurs naturally on Crown land as being a botanical forest product;
establishing a licensing scheme for the purposes of regulating botanical forest products;
issuing, amending, renewing, suspending or cancelling licences;
applications for licences;
fees for licences and applications;
inspectors and inspections for the purposes of enforcing licensing;
appeals.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Chief forester standards for forest and range resources

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In prescribed circumstances, the chief forester may establish, vary or revoke standards respecting

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: tree gene resources for purposes related to this Act, including without restriction the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: registration of seed including, without limitation, determination of genetic quality and imposition of conditions on the use of registered seed;
transfer of seed;
storage of tree seed with the government;
parent trees;
forest stands, trees or seed having rare or unique genetic values;
stocking standards required for a free growing stand,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: fire use,
the preparation of an operational plan,
a forest practice, and
a range practice.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A standard takes effect on the date specified in the standard.
A standard is not effective

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: until 4 months after the notice of the standard and the method for meeting the standard has been published in the Gazette,

to the extent that it conflicts with this Act, the regulations, an agreement under the Forest Act or the Range Act, or a management plan under a tree farm licence, a forest stewardship plan, a range stewardship plan or a range use plan that has been approved before the standard comes into effect, unless the holder of the agreement or plan waives the requirement under this paragraph, and
in respect of a proposed management plan under a tree farm licence, a forest stewardship plan, a range stewardship plan or a range use plan, unless

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the standard comes into effect under paragraph (a) at least 4 months before the plan is submitted for approval, or
the holder of the licence or plan waives the requirement under subparagraph (i).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Forest Practices Advisory Council is continued and renamed as the Forest and Range Practices Advisory Council

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to undertake periodic reviews of the requirements that apply to operational planning and forest practices or range practices under this Act, and
to make recommendations to the minister on any specific matter relevant to this Act that is referred to the council by the minister,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: and by regulation may be disestablished or re-established.
Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the membership of the council, including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the maximum number of persons that may be appointed to the council,
the qualifications of council members,
the terms of appointed members, and
the removal and replacement of members;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the annual report that must be prepared by the council;
the application of sections 138 and 140 to the council.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Pilot Projects for Forest Practices or Range Practices

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Public review and comment required before a pilot project may proceed

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before a pilot project is approved under this Part, the person who proposes the pilot project must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make the proposed pilot project publicly available for

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: review, and
comment,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in accordance with the regulations, and
submit to the minister a summary of the comments received and any actions taken or proposed to address issues raised in the comments.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before a regulation is made under this Part, the minister may establish a public advisory committee with terms of reference the minister considers advisable to make recommendations respecting the proposed pilot project.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tests for making a pilot project regulation
bcl:section.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations under section 173 only if the Lieutenant Governor in Council is satisfied that the proposed pilot project

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is in the public interest,
will be consistent with the objectives set by government,
maintains the role of the board as set out in sections 81 and 83 and Part 8,
provides public access to the following, except in circumstances in which the Lieutenant Governor in Council considers that such public access would jeopardize cultural heritage resources:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: planning documents and assessments used in the proposed pilot project;
records that the regulations require to be prepared for the proposed pilot project, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the area in which a pilot project is proposed does not have a higher level plan, adequately provides for balancing competing values and interests in the area.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Regulation making powers respecting pilot projects

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting pilot projects to experiment with ways to improve the regulatory framework for forest practices or range practices.

Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council, for the purposes of a pilot project, may order by regulation that provisions pertaining to specified subject matter, or specified provisions, of this Act, the Forest Act, the Range Act or the regulations made under any of those Acts do not apply

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to a timber sales manager, or
to the holder of an agreement under the Forest Act or the Range Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council, for the purposes of a pilot project, may make regulations respecting the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: conditions, including providing that all or part of a regulation made under subsection (2) is subject to a condition and requiring that a person to whom the regulation applies comply with the condition;
the suspension or cancellation of a pilot project;
the regulation or prohibition of forest practices or range practices;
the protection of forest resources and of resource features;
compliance and enforcement;
the balancing of competing values and interests;
planning;
monitoring and evaluation of pilot projects;
public review and comment related to pilot projects;
public access to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: planning documents and assessments used in the pilot project, and
records that the regulations require to be prepared for the pilot project.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may exercise for the purposes of a pilot project, all the regulation making powers in this Act, the Forest Act and the Range Act, and
may make regulations that are contrary to a provision of those Acts if that provision is inapplicable because of a regulation made under subsection (2) or (3).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A regulation under this Part with respect to a pilot project does not apply to a timber sales manager or holder of an agreement under the Forest Act or the Range Act until the timber sales manager or holder has consented to take part in the pilot project.

If a regulation under section 173 (2) provides that a provision of an Act does not apply to the holder of an agreement under the Forest Act or the Range Act, or to a timber sales manager or the government, the provision is also inapplicable to their

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: employees or agents, or
contractors, as defined in section 152 of the Forest Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The holder of an agreement under the Forest Act or the Range Act who is the subject of a pilot project must report annually to the minister on the pilot project.
The timber sales manager who is the subject of a pilot project must report annually to the minister on the pilot project.
The minister must make the reports publicly available.
In this Part, except section 216:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Code means the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act as it was immediately before the effective date;
Code regulations means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the regulations under the Code, and
the standards under the Code

bcl:definition.bcl:text: as they were immediately before the effective date;
effective date means the date this section comes into force;
site level plan means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a silviculture prescription under section 22.1 of the Code,
a pre-harvest silviculture prescription or silviculture prescription that was prepared or approved by the district manager under the Forest Act and that was in effect on June 15, 1995,
a site plan prepared under

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: section 21.1 of the Code, or
a regulation made under section 217.1 of the Code, including site plan information specified in a forest development plan whether or not that plan has expired,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a road layout and design prepared under section 60 of the Code, and
a plan prepared under section 189 (3) or 201 (1) of this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this Part, a reference in the Code or the Code regulations to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a district manager preparing a forest development plan or a site plan is deemed to be a reference to a timber sales manager preparing the forest development plan or the site plan, and

a district manager approving or giving effect to a plan, granting an exemption, providing an authorization or attaching a condition is deemed to be a reference to the minister approving or giving effect to the plan, granting the exemption, providing the authorization or attaching the condition, as the case may be.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this Part,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a reference to the Operational and Site Planning Regulation is a reference to the Operational and Site Planning Regulation as it was immediately before the effective date, and
a reference to the Forest Road Regulation is a reference to the Forest Road Regulation as it was immediately before the effective date.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote:
Applicability of certain provisions of Part 6
of this Act for the Code

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Sections 59 to 70, 71 (1), (2), (5) and (6), 72 to 86 and 88 to 103 of this Act apply to and in respect of the Code and the Code regulations.

A person to whom the Code and the Code regulations apply who contravenes a requirement, the contravention of which is an offence under the Code or the Code regulations, commits that offence under the Code or the Code regulations and is liable on conviction

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to a fine not exceeding the maximum amount specified in the Code or the Code regulations for that offence,
to imprisonment not exceeding the maximum amount specified in the Code or the Code regulations for that offence, or
to both.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For contraventions of the Code or the Code regulations, the maximum administrative penalties are as provided for under the Code and the Code regulations.
For the purposes of this section,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the references in section 67 of this Act to sections 52, 50 (2) and 51 must be read as references to sections 96, 100 and 101, respectively, of the Code,
the reference in section 68 (1) of this Act to section 50 (1) must be read as a reference to section 98 of the Code,
the reference in section 71 (2) (a) (i) of this Act to an administrative penalty in an amount that does not exceed a prescribed amount must be read as a reference

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: to

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the penalty provided for under section 117 (1) of the Code, up to and including the amount provided for under that provision, or
that penalty plus the additional penalty provided for in section 119 (3) of the Code, up to and including the amount referred to in that provision, or

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: to

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the penalty provided for in section 119 (1) of the Code, up to and including the amount referred to in that provision, or
that penalty plus the additional penalty provided for in section 119 (3) of the Code, up to and including the amount referred to in that provision,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the references in section 90 of this Act to sections 26 (2), 51 (7), 54 (2), 57 (4), 66 (1) and 74 (1) must be read as references to sections 106 (1), 101 (2), 99 (2), 102 (3), 123 and 118, respectively, of the Code,
the reference in section 93 of this Act to section 46 (1) must be read as a reference to section 45 (1), (3) or (4), as applicable, of the Code,
the references in section 93 of this Act to sections 50 (1), 54 (1), 55 and 57 (1) must be read as references to sections 98, 99 (1), 103 and 102 (1), respectively, of the Code,
the references in section 94 of this Act to sections 52 and 53 must be read as references to sections 96 and 97, respectively, of the Code,
the reference in section 95 of this Act to section 50 must be read as a reference to section 100 of the Code, and
the reference in section 96 of this Act to section 57 must be read as a reference to section 102 of the Code.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless otherwise provided in this Part, this Act, the regulations and the standards apply to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the government, and
a holder of an agreement under the Forest Act or the Range Act or of a special use permit, whether or not the agreement or permit was entered into or issued before on or after the effective date.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) applies despite any wording in the agreement or permit to the contrary.
If an administrative review has commenced before the effective date, sections 129 and 130 of the Code continue to apply to that review, despite the repeal of those sections.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Every area established or continued under the Code as

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an ungulate winter range,
a wildlife habitat area,
a scenic area,
an emergency bark beetle management area,
a community watershed,
an area with significant downstream fisheries values,
an area with significant watershed sensitivity,
a lakeshore management zone,
an interpretive forest site,
a recreation site,
a recreation trail, or
a forest ecosystem network

bcl:section.bcl:text: that was in effect immediately before the effective date is continued under this Act.
All objectives in respect of areas continued under section 180 that were in effect immediately before the effective date are continued as objectives under this Act.
All general wildlife measures that were

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: established under the Code and the Code regulations, and
in effect immediately before the effective date

bcl:section.bcl:text: are continued as general wildlife measures under this Act.
Every cutting permit, issued under an agreement under the Forest Act, that is in effect immediately before the effective date

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is deemed to be a cutting permit under this Act, and
subject to the Forest Act, remains in effect for the term specified in the permit.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Every road permit, issued under the Forest Act, that is in effect immediately before the effective date is deemed to be a road permit under this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), every road use permit, issued under an agreement under the Forest Act, that is in effect immediately before the effective date is deemed to be a road use permit under this Act.
On and after the effective date, every road use permit referred to in section 54 (2) (e) of the Code is no longer valid.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Transition for Forest Operational Plans and Practices

bcl:section.bcl:text: This Division does not apply to or in respect of the holder of a woodlot licence or of a licence to cut.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A forest development plan that was approved or given effect under the Code and that was in effect immediately before the effective date remains in effect until whichever happens first,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the agreement for which the plan was prepared expires and is not replaced or is cancelled, surrendered or otherwise terminated,
the plan is replaced with a forest stewardship plan prepared in accordance with this Act,
subject to paragraph (d) and to subsection (3), December 31, 2006, or
if the plan is for a community forest agreement, the end of the term specified in the approval of the plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1) (a), a forest development plan that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: was approved or given effect under the Code and that was in effect immediately before the effective date, and
immediately before the effective date pertained to a pre-existing licence referred to in section 24.2 of the Forest Act, as that section read immediately before its repeal,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: remains in effect for the forest licence, if any, that replaces the pre-existing licence until whichever of the following happens first:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the forest licence expires and is not replaced or is cancelled, surrendered or otherwise terminated;
the plan is replaced with a forest stewardship plan prepared in accordance with this Act;
subject to subsection (3), December 31, 2006.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The holder of a forest development plan must prepare any amendments to the plan or replacement of the plan required under the Code.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council by regulation may substitute a date that is no later than December 31, 2007 for the date referred to in subsectionÂ (1)Â (c) orÂ (1.1)Â (e).

bcl:editorialnote.in:em: [Note: B.C. Reg. 361/2006 substituted March 31, 2007 for the dates referred to in subsectionsÂ (1)Â (c) andÂ (1.1)Â (e).]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Preparing a forest development plan during the transition period

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite section 3, but subject to subsection (6) (a), on or before December 31, 2005 a timber sales manager or a holder of an agreement under the Forest Act may prepare and submit for the district manager's approval a forest development plan under this section.
The Code and the Code regulations apply to forest development plans prepared under subsection (1).
For the purposes of sections 21 and 22 of the Operational and Site Planning Regulation,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a forest development plan referred to in subsection (1) is deemed to be a "subsequently proposed forest development plan", and

the cutblocks and roads referred to in those sections continue to have the same protection afforded to them in respect of the circumstances in which the district manager may or may not refuse to approve a subsequently proposed forest development plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A forest development plan referred to in subsection (1) remains in effect until whichever happens first,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the agreement for which the plan was prepared expires and is not replaced or is cancelled, surrendered or otherwise terminated,
the plan is replaced with a forest stewardship plan prepared in accordance with this Act,
subject to paragraph (d) and to subsection (6) (b), December 31, 2006, or
if the plan is for a community forest agreement, the end of the term specified in the approval of the plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The holder of a forest development plan referred to in subsection (1) must prepare any amendments to the plan or replacement of the plan required under the Code.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council by regulation

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may substitute a date that is no later than December 31, 2006 for the date referred to in subsection (1), and
may substitute a date that is no later than December 31, 2007 for the date referred to in subsectionÂ (4)Â (c).

bcl:editorialnote.in:em: [Note: B.C. Reg. 361/2006 substituted March 31, 2007 for the date referred to in subsectionÂ (4)Â (c).]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Site level planning for cutblocks before the approval of a forest stewardship plan

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A site level plan for a cutblock that was in effect immediately before the effective date remains in effect.
The Code and the Code regulations apply to a site level plan referred to in subsection (1).
The

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: timber sales manager, or
holder of an agreement under the Forest Act

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: who has a forest development plan referred to in section 187 or 188, and who has not prepared a site plan under the Code before the effective date, must prepare the site plan in accordance with the Code and the Code regulations.
Subsection (3) does not require a site plan if one is not required under the Code.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Site plans for roads before the approval of a forest stewardship plan

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A road layout and design that was in effect immediately before the effective date remains in effect.
The Code and the Code regulations apply to a road layout and design referred to in subsection (1).
The

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: timber sales manager, or
the holder of an agreement under the Forest Act

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: who has a forest development plan referred to in section 187 or 188, and who has not prepared a road layout and design under the Code and the Code regulations before the effective date, must prepare a road layout and design in accordance with the Code and the Code regulations and, if required, obtain approval of the road layout and design.
Subsection (3) does not require a road layout and design if one is not required under the Code or the Code regulations.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Operations in cutblocks begun under the Code

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the holder of an agreement under the Forest Act, before the effective date, has begun harvesting on an area in a cutblock, the holder must comply with the requirements of the Code and the Code regulations that pertain to the holder for the area.
If a timber sales manager, before the effective date,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has authorized harvesting in a cutblock, and
harvesting has begun on the area

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the timber sales manager must comply with the requirements of the Code and the Code regulations that pertain to the government for the area.
The government must comply with the requirements of the Code and the Code regulations that pertain to areas for which the government

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is required to establish a free growing stand under section 70 (2) of the Code, and
has assumed the responsibility for carrying out a prescription or site plan under section 71 (3) of the Code.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Operations in cutblocks begun after the effective date and before the approval of a forest stewardship plan

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the holder of an agreement under the Forest Act, on or after the effective date, begins harvesting on an area that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is in a cutblock, and
is subject to a forest development plan referred to in section 187 or 188,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the holder must comply with the requirements of the Code and the Code regulations that pertain to the holder for the area.
If the timber sales manager, on or after the effective date, authorizes harvesting on an area that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is in a cutblock, and
is subject to a forest development plan referred to in section 187 or 188,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the timber sales manager must comply with the requirements of the Code and the Code regulations that pertain to the government for the area.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Road operations begun under the Code

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the holder of an agreement under the Forest Act, before the effective date, begins construction, maintenance or deactivation of a road, the holder must comply with the requirements of the Code and the Code regulations that pertain to the holder for the road.
If the timber sales manager, before the effective date,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has authorized construction, maintenance or deactivation of a road, and
the construction, maintenance or deactivation, as the case may be, has begun,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the timber sales manager must comply with the requirements of the Code and the Code regulations that pertain to the government for the road.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Road operations begun on or after the effective date and before the approval of a forest stewardship plan

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, on or after the effective date, the holder of an agreement under the Forest Act begins road construction, maintenance or deactivation on an area that is subject to a forest development plan or site plan, the holder must comply with the requirements of the Code and the Code regulations that pertain to the holder for the road construction, maintenance or deactivation.

If, on or after the effective date, the timber sales manager authorizes road construction, maintenance or deactivation on an area that is subject to a forest development plan or site plan, the timber sales manager must comply with the requirements of the Code and the Code regulations that pertain to the timber sales manager for the road construction, maintenance or deactivation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applying for cutting permits and road permits before a forest stewardship plan is approved

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite section 3, if a person is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the holder of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a major licence,
a timber sale licence that requires the holder of the licence to prepare a forest stewardship plan, or
a community forest agreement, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the holder of a forest development plan that is in effect,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the person may obtain a cutting permit, road permit or licence to cut in accordance with the Forest Act, the Code and the Code regulations.
Despite section 3, a timber sales manager who is the holder of a forest development plan that is in effect, in accordance with the Forest Act, the Code and the Code regulations, may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: invite applications for, or enter into, a timber sale licence to which subsection (1) does not apply, and
issue a road permit.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Protection of cutblocks and roads from a forest development plan into a forest stewardship plan

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except in prescribed circumstances, a proposed forest stewardship plan must be considered to have received the minister's approval under section 16 (1) for the parts, if any, of the forest stewardship plan that pertain to an area in a forest development unit that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a cutblock, if the cutblock has been included in a forest development plan, with the assessments required in sections 16, 17, 36.1 and 37 of the Operational and Site Planning Regulation shown as completed, and
a road, if the road has been included in a forest development plan, with the assessments required in section 5 of the Forest Road Regulation shown as completed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A proposed forest stewardship plan must be considered to have received the minister's approval under section 16 (1) for the parts, if any, of the plan that pertain to a cutblock or road that has been included as part of a forest development plan that is in effect on the date of the submission of the forest stewardship plan to the minister, unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: one or more of the following events have occurred during the period specified in subsection (3):

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an enactment applicable to the forest development unit has been made or amended;
an objective set by government has been established or varied;
an area of land has been designated by regulation as a community watershed;
an area of land that was a community watershed has been varied by regulation and the watershed as varied is applicable to the forest development unit;
timber in the vicinity of the forest development unit has suffered catastrophic damage, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minister considers that the forest development unit is inconsistent with the events described in paragraph (a) that have occurred.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The specified period under subsection (2) (a) begins 4 months before the date the existing forest development plan was submitted for approval and ends 4 months before the date the proposed forest stewardship plan was submitted for approval.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of approval of a forest stewardship plan

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A forest stewardship plan approved under section 16 replaces any forest development plan that, on the date the forest stewardship plan was approved, was in effect for the part of the area under the forest development plan that is in the area under the forest stewardship plan.

Any site level information in a forest development plan at the time of its replacement under subsection (1) by a forest stewardship plan continues to be applicable for cutblocks in the forest stewardship plan area that have been harvested or are subject to a cutting permit.
The replacement under subsection (1) of a forest development plan by a forest stewardship plan does not affect a site plan prepared before the replacement.

Unless otherwise specified in a forest stewardship plan, the approval of the plan does not affect the requirements that must be met for any area in which timber harvesting or road construction has begun before the approval of the plan.
If, before the replacement under subsection (1) of a part of a forest development plan,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the holder

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: begins harvesting of a cutblock, and
is required to establish a free growing stand on an area harvested, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the stocking standards specified in the plan apply to the net area to be reforested,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: unless otherwise specified in a forest stewardship plan, the stocking standards in the plan remain in effect until the free growing stand is established.

Subject to subsection (7), a person who begins timber harvesting or road construction on an area after the approval of a forest stewardship plan must comply with the requirements of this Act, the regulations, the standards and the forest stewardship plan that pertain to the person for the area.
Unless otherwise specified in a forest stewardship plan, the Code and the Code regulations continue to apply to an area that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in a cutblock and subject to a cutting permit or licence to cut in effect on the date the forest stewardship plan was approved,
described in a timber sale licence in effect on the date the forest stewardship plan was approved, or
in a road right of way and subject to a road permit in effect on the date the forest stewardship plan was approved.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The holder of a forest stewardship plan may amend the site level information referred to in subsection (2) in accordance with the Code and the Code regulations.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a holder of a woodlot licence has carried out a forest practice in the woodlot licence area before the effective date and the requirements of the Code and the Code regulations that pertain to that area have not been completed before the effective date, the holder must comply with those requirements.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A forest development plan that is held by the holder of a woodlot licence, was approved under the Code and was in effect immediately before the effective date is deemed to be a forest development plan under this Act and remains in effect until whichever happens first,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the agreement for which the plan was prepared expires and is not replaced or is cancelled, surrendered or otherwise terminated,
the plan is replaced with a woodlot licence plan prepared in accordance with this Act, or
subject to subsection (2), the later of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: December 31, 2006, and
the end of the term specified in the approval of the plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council by regulation may substitute a date that is no later than December 31, 2007 for the date referred to in subsectionÂ (1)Â (c)Â (i).

bcl:editorialnote.in:em: [Note: B.C. Reg. 361/2006 substituted December 31, 2007 for the date referred to in subsection (1)Â (c)Â (i).]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Preparing a forest development plan during the transition period

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite section 12, but subject to subsection (4), on or before December 31, 2005, a holder of a woodlot licence may prepare and submit for the district manager's approval a forest development plan under this section.
Each of the following apply to forest development plans prepared under subsection (1):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Part 3 of the Code;
the Code regulations respecting woodlot licences.
